title: Integration Studio—Core Content integration
content:
OpenText Core Content is a cloud-based content management and collaboration platform designed to help organizations manage and share their documents and content securely. The integration of SMAX with Core Content enables you to embed a Core Content widget in Service Management so that users can leverage the industry-leading content management capabilities powered by Core Content. 

Overview

With this integration, SMAX users can click a Related documents tab in a record to launch an embedded Core Content widget, which offers the following benefits.

Enterprise document management 

The embedded widget centralizes document storage and access. It ensures that all documents, regardless of their source, are stored securely in one location for easy retrieval and management. 

Workflow automation

The embedded widget automates, manages, and tracks document-centric processes. It streamlines tasks, routes documents, assigns responsibilities, ensures compliance, and enhances collaboration for efficient business operations. 

Version control

The embedded widget tracks the version history and ensures that everyone accesses and works on the latest document versions, minimizing confusion. 

Secure external sharing

This capability enables controlled and audited sharing of documents with external partners, clients, or vendors. This ensures that sensitive data remains protected. 

Set up the integration

The following describes the procedure to set up this integration. 

Prerequisites

Before you begin, make sure you have met the following prerequisites.

A valid Core Content subscription

You must have a valid Core Content subscription in the OT2/OCP cloud.

Client Id and client secret

A Core Content organization administrator must create an extension app by using the OpenText Developer site (developer.opentext.com > Console tab > <your organization>). A pair of service clients are automatically created during the app creation process. The administrator must send you the client Id, client secret, and the description for the confidential service client. For details, see the Core Content Admin Center Developer Help.

Single Sign-On (SSO)

To enable the user to access Core Content documents in Service Management without the need to log in each time, the SMAX and Core Content deployments must use the same identity provider (IdP) for SAML-based SSO. For this integration, we have certified Azure Active Directory-based SSO.

For details about the Core Content SSO setup, refer to "Setting up SSO and auto provisioning with Azure Active Directory" in the Core Content Admin Center Tenant Administrator Help. The tenant administrator should follow the exact steps in the documentation to set up SSO (and auto provisioning); the only step that can be skipped is the last step, which is for sending the URL of the app to end users. This step isn't needed because SMAX users don't directly access Core Content through the URL.

Configure in the Core Content Admin Center

A Core Content tenant administrator needs to do the following in the Core Content Admin Center.

Obtain the authentication Id

Open the authentication schema that was created during the SSO configuration process. Make a note of the ID at the end of the SAML SSO URL (the value after authhandler=) displayed on the authentication schema details page. You will need this value when configuring the integration in Service Management.

Obtain the subscription name or Id

Browse to the app in which the workspaces will be created. On the Overview page, you can find the app's subscription name and subscription Id by clicking the Subscription details  button. Make a note of the subscription name or Id. You will need it later when configuring the integration in Service Management.

Add SMAX as a trusted site

Add a trusted site for SMAX on the Trusted sites page, in this format: https://<fully qualified domain name for SMAX>.

Configure in Core Content Administration

A Core Content business administrator must configure workspace types, which will be used by the SMAX Integration Studio to create workspaces. See the section below for workspace type configuration guidelines.

The workspace types must contain:

  • Only one workspace location.
  • Only one workspace template.
  • Only one attribute, with the name EntityId. This is the only attribute supported by an out-of-the-box scenario template available in Service Management. Later, you can add more attributes as described in the Customize the scenario to support more attributes section below.
  • No roles. Roles are not supported in workspaces created by this integration.
  • Appropriately configured permission templates. See the Permission configuration guidelines section below for permission configuration best practices.

For each workspace type, make a note of the following values, which you will need when configuring integration scenarios in Service Management.

  • The Item ID of the workspace type
  • The name of the included workspace template

For details about how to configure workspace types, refer to "Adding workspace types not linked to business objects" in the Core Content Administrator Help.

Workspace type configuration guidelines

When determining how many workspace types you need to create, consider the following factors:

  • Whether you want the users to view entity-specific metadata in the workspaces
  • What folder structures you want different users to see
  • How you want to manage permissions in Core Content

If you want users to see customized folder structures for each SMAX record type (entity) in the SMAX Core Content widget, and you want the workspaces to include entity-specific metadata, then you can consider creating one workspace type for each SMAX record type. Otherwise, if you decide to use a generic folder structure for all record types and don't need to include entity-specific metadata, you can use one workspace type for all record types.

Another approach is to create one workspace type with folders for various record types and use permission templates to restrict access to each folder to people who handle the record type in Service Management.

The number of workspace types also decides the number of SMAX integration scenarios that you need to create and configure. For example, if you decide to use one workspace type for all record types, you can configure only one integration scenario, and select the same scenario for all record types on the Core Content Integration Configuration page.

Permission configuration guidelines

Use Core Content permission templates to assign permissions to appropriate users and groups when configuring the workspace type. Because users inherit the read permission from the workspace location folder, you can add restrictive permission templates on folders or document types to prohibit user access.

As a best practice, set up users and groups in your identity provider (such as Azure AD) and synchronize the users and groups to SMAX and Core Content. Then you can efficiently and consistently grant permissions to the same set of users and groups in both systems.

For example, if you add a Contract Manager group that contains all contract managers, you can do the following:

  • In SMAX: assign the Contract Manager role to the Contract Manager group
  • In the Core Content Contract workspace type: Assign Full Control permission to the Contract Manager group. You can assign lower permission levels to other users. For example, assign Read permission to the Contract Viewer group.

This way, the SMAX Contract module as well as contract-related documents stored in Core Content are restricted only to agents dealing with contracts, and you don't need to set up and maintain different sets of groups in both systems.

Configure in Core Content

A Core Content user with enough permission must assign the following permissions in all workspace location folders for the configured workspace types:

  • Assign the Full control permission to the service client (identified by its description) mentioned in the Prerequisites section
  • Assign the Read permission to Everyone

Alternatively, the user can add these permissions in the Enterprise volume, so that the user doesn't need to add permissions in many folders.

For details about how to add permissions, refer to the "Add permissions" section in the Core Content User Help.

Configure SMAX

The configuration process in Service Management includes these steps: 

  1. Prepare an integration user
  2. Create a Core Content endpoint
  3. Create an integration record from Integration Studio
  4. Configure scenarios based on the Create workspace scenario template
  5. Customize the scenarios as required

Prepare an integration user

Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user:

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user.

  2. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin, navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and then assign a role with the On-Premise Bridge/Integration Administrator permission.

    Alternatively, add the Tenant Admin role to grant general access.

Configure an endpoint

Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the integration administrator.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.
  3. Click Add.
  4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint (for example, Core Content), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.
  5. Click Configure and complete the following fields:
    Field Value
    General configuration
    Agent Select Agentless for a direct connection to Core Content.
    Authentication type Select OAuth 2.0
    Protocol Select https.
    Base URL Enter the base URL of the Core Content API: https://<region>.api.opentext.com. Example: https://na-1.api.opentext.com
    Certificate type Leave it empty.
    Certificate format Leave it empty.
    Server certificate Leave it empty.
    Enable email notification for token expiration Optional. If you want the Integration Studio to send notification emails to integration administrators when it fails to refresh the access token, select this checkbox and specify the email recipients in the Recipients field below.
    Recipients Optional. Specify the email recipients.
    Get Token configuration

    Grant Type

    Select Client Credentials.
    Client ID The client Id for the confidential service client associated with the Core Content extension app.
    Client Secret The client secret associated with the client Id.
    Token URL

    Enter the Core Content tenant token URL:

    https://<region>.api.opentext.com/tenants/<tenant_id>/oauth2/token
    Scope Leave it empty.
    Send client Id and secret Keep the default In body.

Create an integration

Perform the following steps to create an integration based on the OpenText Core Content connector. 

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio. 
  2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
  3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current SMAX system and activate the integration.
  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
  5. Select Core Content (under OpenText) as the connector, select the Core Content endpoint that you created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
  6. Click Save. 

Configure scenarios

Perform the following steps to add and configure scenarios using the predefined template.

As an example, the following procedure describes how to configure a scenario for the Contract record type. Use the same procedure to create scenarios for other record types, and for each record type specify a different workspace type and the corresponding workspace template in Step 5.
  1. Click Add scenario. 

  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter Create workspace for Contract.

  3. In the Template field, select Create workspace (under OpenText Core Content) from the list. 

    Using templates will make the integration configuration easier than starting from scratch. If you don't select this option, you'll have to manually add your own logic, starting from a blank page.

  4. Click Save to add the scenario.

  5. Click the Settings rule to expand it, and then enter the following details.

    Parameter Description
    workspaceTypeName The Item ID of the workspace type for the Contract record type.
    workspaceTemplateDisplayName The name of the workspace template included in the workspace type.

  6. Click Save.

Customize the scenario to support more attributes (optional)

The Create workspace scenario template supports adding only one SMAX attribute in Core Content workspaces.

If you want to add another attribute (for example, the contract name) to the workspace, do the following:

  1. In Core Content Administration, add the Name attribute in the workspace type for the Contract record type.
  2. In SMAX, make the following scenario rule updates. 

Update the "Create business object configuration" rule (rule number 7) 

Add two properties with the following details. 

Property Details
1 Key: 
<attributeMappingOverride[1].WorkspaceAttribute>
Value:  
json_parser(
  WksTypeResponse.data,
  "$.root_folder_type.attributes[?(@.display_name == 'Name')].name"
)[0];
2

Key: <attributeMappingOverride[1].BusinessObjectAttribute>

Value: 'Name'

The key and value of the properties follow a pattern. When you add another attribute, copy the keys above and increment the number in the brackets. For example, the keys for the third attribute should be <attributeMappingOverride[2].WorkspaceAttribute> and <attributeMappingOverride[2].BusinessObjectAttribute>. For the values, copy the values above and replace Name with the name of the new attribute that you added in the workspace type.

Add a local system "Get record" rule

Add a local system Get record rule after the Create business object configuration rule to retrieve the name of the contract, as shown in the following figure.

Update the "Create or update workspace" rule (rule number 9)

In the Create or update workspace rule (rule number 9), update the value for the <businessObjectsInfo[0].properties> key to add the following mapping for the Name attribute, and be sure to add a comma after the existing mapping to separate the mappings.

{ name: 'Name', value: [Contract.Name] }

If you add another attribute, replace the value (Name in the above example) for the name key with the name of the attribute. Replace Contract.Name with the object and property defined in the Output section of a preceding rule that you add to retrieve the attribute value.

Enable the Core Content widget

Do the following to enable the Core Content widget for desired SMAX record types:

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the integration administrator.
  2. Go to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Configuration.
  3. Select Core Content in the left pane.
  4. In the Widget URL field, replace the placeholder text for the Core Content hostname, subscription name or ID, and authentication ID (the Auth partition Id placeholder) with their actual value.
  5. Select the Active checkbox to enable the integration.
  6. Click Save.
  7. Click Add. The system displays the Add configuration for record type dialog.
  8. Select the record type for which to display the Core Content widget. The system displays the Core Content configuration page for the record type.
  9. Select the configured integration and scenario for creating workspaces for the record type.
  10. Select the Active checkbox to enable the integration for the record type.
  11. Repeat Step 7 through Step 10 for the remaining SMAX record types for which you want to enable the widget.

Configure settings to allow widget display

To display the Core Content widget in Service Management, you must configure content security policies as follows.

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Configuration > Application Settings.
  3. Click Configure next to the Content security policy option.
  4. Click Add item, and then select Frame-src.
  5. Add the Core Content tenant's URLs. For example,  *.<region>.opentext.com *.microsoftonline.com mailto: in the Frame-src field. The Core Content tenant URL varies by region. Replace <region> with the region for your environment, such as ot2, or us.
  6. Click Add item, and then select Frame-ancestors.
  7. Add the Core Content tenant's URLs. For example, *.<region>.opentext.com *.microsoftonline.com in the Frame-ancestors field. The Core Content tenant URL varies by region. Replace <region> with the region for your environment, such as ot2, or us.
  8. Click OK.
  9. Click Save.

Use and manage the integration

Follow the instructions below to use and manage the integration. 

Access the Core Content widget

To access the Core Content widget for a record type, navigate to the page for the record type (for example, go to Plan > Contract for the Contract record type), open a record, and then click the Related documents tab.

If this is the first time the tab is clicked for the record by any user, it will take some time for the system to display the widget because the system is running the configured scenario to dynamically create the workspace. Subsequent access to the tab will be faster.

Control the display of the Core Content widget

If you want to temporarily disable the Core Content widget for records of a certain record type, go to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Configuration, click the record type under Core Content in the left pane, clear the Active checkbox, and then click Save.

If you want to temporarily disable the Core Content widget for all record types, go to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Configuration, click Core Content in the left pane, clear the Active checkbox, and then click Save.

Use the Active checkbox to control the widget display instead of using the Remove button on the Core Content configuration page for particular record types. Use the button to remove record types only when you make changes to integration scenarios (see the next section) or decide to permanently stop using Core Content. Removing the record types won't delete workspaces in Core Content though. To do that, you need to delete them manually in Core Content.

Reconfigure record types after making changes to the integration scenarios

If you need to make changes to the integration scenario for a record type (including changing the details of the existing scenario or replacing it with a new scenario), and you want the system to re-create workspaces using the updated scenario for records that already have workspaces created, do the following:

  1. Remove the record type (using the Remove button on the Core Content configuration page for the record type).
  2. Add and configure the record type again. 
    You need to use this approach because the system triggers integration scenarios to create workspaces only upon the first click of the Related documents tab. The only way to make the system trigger the updated integration scenarios for the same record again is to remove and then add the record type again.
  3. In Core Content, move documents (if any) from the existing workspaces (based on the previous version of the scenario) for the records to the new workspaces.

Troubleshoot the integration

For troubleshooting information, see Troubleshoot Core Content integration.
